thread.title: $A gets a boost from commodity rally
thread.title_full: $A gets a boost from commodity rally

title: $A gets a boost from commodity rally
text:
Fri, Aug 28, 2015, 6:03 PM AEST - Australia Markets closed $A gets a boost from commodity rally AAP – 20 minutes ago Print 
The Australian dollar is higher as optimism returns and commodities and sharemarkets rally. 
At 1700 AEST on Friday, the local unit was trading at 71.67 US cents, up from 71.13 cents on Thursday. 
The local share market rose 0.6 per cent and Asian share markets rallied, the highlight being Shanghai's more than four per cent gain, in stark contrast to the steep falls suffered earlier in the week. 
St George chief economist Hans Kunnen said firmer commodity prices helped the Australian dollar lift off its recent lows. 
"The Australian dollar has the potential to edge higher against the US dollar if commodity prices pick up and if the US refrains from hiking rates in September," he said. 
US economic growth of 3.7 per cent in the June quarter helped boost oil prices and commodity currencies, Mr Kunnen said. 
The focus for local investors will be on Tuesday's Reserve Bank interest rate announcement and Wednesday's June quarter economic growth figures. 
The RBA is expected to keep the cash rate unchanged but the focus will be on the impact of recent stock market turmoil on its thinking on the likelihood of future rate moves. 
At 1700 AEST, the Australian dollar was at 86.75 Japanese yen, up from Thursday's close of 85.55 yen, and at 63.61 euro cents, up from 62.78 euro cents. 
The Australian bond market was weaker, with demand for safe haven assets falling as traders move into riskier assets, Nomura head of macro products Jon Linton said. 
"It feels like some of the frenzy and fear has dissipated," he said. 
"The actions by Chinese authorities - the supporting of the market and the cutting of interest rates - seems to have calmed things down." 
Mr Linton said the fact that the Australian government will continue to issue longer dated bonds will help support the bond market into the future. 
Next week's economic data could also help bonds. 
"We are expecting a soft GDP next week, which will act as a support for the local bond market," Mr Linton said. 
At 1630 AEST on Friday, the September 2015 10-year bond futures contract was trading at 97.235 (implying a yield of 2.765 per cent), down from 97.260 (2.740 per cent) on Thursday. 
The September 2015 three-year bond futures contract was at 98.170 (1.830 per cent), down from 98.210 (1.790 per cent). @y7finance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook RBA unlikely to change rate stance AAP 
The Reserve Bank is expected to look through recent market turmoil and keep the cash rate unchanged for the foreseeable …
